doc.field: FDP may keep money - for the time being

The FDP party will not have to pay back the contentious 10.5 million marks they received from government, for the time being. They will, however, get 'backpay' to the tune of 5.7 million marks, a sum that had been frozen so far while the courts were still looking at the matter. This followed a decision by the Muenster Administrative Court, which effectively quashed the former ruling by a Cologne court. The latter had decided last November that government would have to ask for the monies to be refunded immediately.
Mr Scholz prime candidate for Berlin CDU

Former Defence Minister Scholz will be the prime candidate running for Berlin's CDU at the upcoming federal elections this autumn (fall). The expert in constitutional law got 224 out of 272 votes. Mr Scholz had already been the prime candidate for Berlin in 1994.
Union only interested in more pay

The union for workers in the service industry wants to go for higher wages only - at the upcoming award-negotiations. They want 4.5% more pay for some 175,000 staff in Hesse, and that would be it. The union expects the employers to play ball within a short time.
Tiff between coalition partners about nuclear storage facility

The intermediate storage facility for nuclear waste at Lubmin in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania caused a bit of a tiff between coalition partners. Minister for Internal Affairs Jaeger, of the CDU, had agreed to setting up the storage facility for nuclear waste from the nuclear power plants at Greifswald and Rheinsberg, among others. The SPD, however, thought that he had breached the coalition agreement by doing so.
Huge deployment of police for transport of nuclear waste

The biggest deployment of police ever will take place when nuclear waste in a so-called CASTOR-container will be sent to the intermediate storage facility at Aarhaus. A total of 6 containers will be on their way at the end of March. A year ago, 30,000 police were deployed for the transport of a container to another storage facility (at Gorleben), but this pale in comparison to this year's numbers.

Police had had some success in the investigation of schoolgirl Karla's murder, as they probably managed to retrace where her murderer went when he fled. Two witnesses claimed they saw him race his car from Wilhermsdorf to the next village. Police issued bills asking the general public for hints and tip-offs. 12-year old Karla from Wilhermsdorf near Fuerth was on her way to school on 22 January, when she was raped by a person unknown so far, and dumped in a pond. She died 5 days later.
Tennis: Ms Graf and Ms Rittner lose double at Hanover tournament

A day after she was defeated in the single, Steffi Graf also lost the double at the Hanover tournament. In the quarter-finals she and her partner Barbara Rittner lost against Jana Novotna (Czechoslovakia) and Marnon Ballgraf (Netherlands) 4:6, 6:2 and 6:2.
